Roger Waters wrote the lyrics. While many people thought the song was about drugs, Waters claims it is not. The lyrics are about what he felt like as a child when he was sick with a fever.
Dave Gilmour wrote the music while he was working on a solo album in 1978. He brought it to The Wall sessions and Waters wrote lyrics for it.
This was the last song Waters and Gilmour wrote together. In 1986 Waters left the band and felt there should be no Pink Floyd without him.
When this song starts, it sounds like it is coming from an AM radio somewhere in the distance. It represents the distance between the listener and the music.
This was a rare case of the Pink Floyd primary songwriters Roger Waters and David Gilmour mutually collaborating on a song - they rarely wrote together.
This is one of the few songs Roger Waters continued to play at his shows after leaving Pink Floyd that David Gilmour helped him write.
Paul McCartney wrote this song. It was inspired by his mother, Mary, who died when he was 14. Many people thought \'\'Mother Mary\'\' was a biblical reference when they heard it.
John Lennon hated this song because of it\'s apparent Christian overtones. He made the comment before recording it, "And now we'd like to do Hark The Angels Come."

The Beatles weren\'t the first to release this song - Aretha Franklin was. She recorded it in December 1969, and it was released on her album This Girl\'s In Love With You in January 1970, two months before The Beatles.

This song is written from the perspective of a dying sheriff: \'\'Mama, take this badge off of me; I can\'t use it anymore; It\'s gettin\' dark, too dark for me to see; I feel like I\'m knockin\' on heaven\'s door\'\'.
Guns N\' Roses covered this on their 1991 album, Use Your Illusion II. They played it in 1992 at a tribute concert for Freddie Mercury, the lead singer of Queen, who had died of AIDS.
In October 2007, 1,730 guitarists in Shillong, India strummed this song for five minutes to set a world record for the largest ever guitar ensemble.

Nothing beats regularly putting your hands on the guitar and practicing the latest lessons. Even 10 minutes a day can make difference!
Try to practise both standing up and sitting down.
Do not hook your left hand\'s thumb over the top of the fret board, it is a bad habit. It even has a name: "Death Grip".
Do not try to rush. Always start slowly, get used to tempo and rhythm.
When your muscles start to creak and the fingertips are stinging, take a break and relax for a while.
Don’t be put off if things don’t sound right at first!
It is always good idea to learn some music theory.
Most of all though remember to always have fun when playing.
